title: UK carbon benchmark hits record low on industrial weakness
subtitle: (Montel) The UK’s benchmark carbon contract plunged on Monday to its lowest ever price since the creation of the country’s emissions trading scheme in 2021 amid weak industrial indicators, before making a slight recovery in afternoon trading.
body:
The Dec 25 UKA was last seen trading at GBP 33.60/t, up GBP 2.06 on Friday’s settlement.
Earlier today, however, the contract hit GBP 31.10/t, a fresh record low price for the front-December UKA contract on a rolling basis, according to Ice exchange data.
“Despite a cold spell that boosted gas power generation and resulted in a bullish first auction of the year, UKAs entered the year on a bearish note,” said consultancy ClearBlue Markets in a note.
The first UK emissions auction of the year – held on 8 January – saw more than 2.2m allowances successfully cleared at GBP 32.80/t, Ice data showed.
The previous record low trade for the front-December UKA contract was GBP 31.10/t on 29 January 2024.
“Negative industrial indicators”“This bearish trend in the UK carbon market was likely driven by negative industrial indicators, reduced fund positions and a lack of regulatory signals,” ClearBlue Markets added.
Last week, the UK’s Office for National Statistics (ONS) released the index of production for November 2024, which revealed that industrial output in the country fell by 0.4% in that month.
This was the third consecutive monthly fall in production output, ONS data showed.
Speculative investors’ net long position in UKAs reached 7.9m tonnes as of 10 January, having previously been net short by 1.5m tonnes the week before.
ClearBlue Markets also pointed to a lack of clarity surrounding a supply adjustment mechanism (SAM).
A SAM is a type of market stability policy that automatically amends the supply of allowances in the market in response to certain pre-determined criteria and market conditions.
The UK ETS has operated without a SAM since its launch in 2021. The government’s UK ETS Authority began a consultation on introducing the SAM in December 2023, but it remains unclear when this mechanism will be introduced.
Investment fund positions would likely decrease if SAM introduction delays occurred, the consultancy said.
